reportSettings.title: Report Settings
reportSettings.description: Configure report language and profile used to personalize outputs.
reportSettings.reportLanguageDescription: Choose the language for the reports
reportSettings.organizationProfileDescription: Your report will be personalized based on this profile.
reportSettings.profileExplanation1: This information helps the system analyze how well each part aligns with your machining capabilities. The profile is used directly in the Shop Alignment section of every report (GOOD / PARTIAL / COOPERATION / LOW / UNKNOWN).
reportSettings.profileExplanation2: By telling us, for example, what materials you machine, what tolerances you prefer, and what operations you specialize in, the system can generate more accurate and realistic recommendations — and your entire team will get consistent RFQ evaluations.
reportSettings.profileExplanation3: You can write the profile in your native language.
reportSettings.example1Text: We specialize in high-precision CNC milling and turning of aluminum and stainless steel. We avoid tolerances below 0.01 mm. We have CMM for inspection but no grinding capabilities.
reportSettings.example2Text: Prototype machining 1–20 pcs. We accept complex geometries but not high-volume production. No hardened steels or grinding operations.
reportSettings.example3Text: CNC turning and milling of aluminum, brass, and mild steel. Typical tolerances ±0.05 mm. No 5-axis or welding.
reportSettings.profilePlaceholder: Describe your shop: capabilities, materials, machines, tolerances, volume preferences, etc.

hero.badge: AI assistant for processing technical drawings in manufacturing
hero.description: Partonomy automatically reads engineering drawings, extracts key metadata, manufacturing complexity and more, helping you quickly decide – is it worth quoting or declining right away. With every uploaded drawing, you're building a parts database in unified, serialized format.

howItWorks.title: How it works
howItWorks.subtitle: Three simple steps to faster decision-making.
howItWorks.step1Desc: Simply upload drawings as PDF, TIFF, PNG or JPEG – works even with regular scans from email. Recommended: 1 part = 1 page for best results.
howItWorks.step2Desc: System extracts material, dimensions, tolerances, GD&T and identifies critical points and cost drivers. Metadata is stored in structured format, ready for further use in your system.
howItWorks.step3Desc: Each part gets a clear report and simple score. RFQ triage takes minutes instead of hours. Plus, drawings become a clear parts database you can work with further.

features.title: What you get
features.subtitle: Say goodbye to manual transcription from PDFs and TIFFs!

list.title: Drawing list
list.desc: All drawings in one place. Sorted, marked with processing status and ready for decision. You see the part envelope, basic description, manufacturing complexity and how well the part fits your capabilities.
list.complexityDesc: AI searches for critical tolerances, GD&T, surface/heat treatments and other typical cost factors. Result is a concise, understandable report for each part – in your team's language. Plus, you can export the report to Excel, for example.
list.classificationDesc: System automatically recognizes part taxonomy and assigns scores (complexity, risk, alignment) according to typical engineering criteria. Everything is stored as structured data – with each drawing you're building a parts database and can export data to your process.
list.customOutputDesc: Simply describe your workshop profile – what materials you machine, what tolerances you prefer and what you're strong at. System then evaluates shop alignment for each part based on how well it matches your capabilities. 'Cooperation or can we handle it ourselves?'
list.revisionsDesc: When a new revision index arrives, Partonomy automatically alerts you. In Inbox you immediately see it's a newer drawing version – without manual table checking and file comparison.
list.projectsDesc: In Pro version you create projects, link parts to specific RFQ and team can work together in one workflow. Instead of email chaos you have one place for RFQ triage, internal decisions and follow-up steps.

features.earlyAccess: Partonomy is currently in Early Access mode. We focus on RFQs (requests for quote) for machining and manufacturing, gradually adding more features based on feedback from early users.

faq.title: Frequently asked questions
faq.subtitle: Answers to the most common questions we get from manufacturing companies.
faq.q1: What types of drawings does Partonomy support?
faq.a1: Partonomy is designed specifically for 2D technical drawings in raster format, typically arriving as attachments in RFQ emails. We support PDF, TIFF, PNG and JPEG formats – including scans and older documentation.
faq.q2: Does Partonomy support CAD drawings or 3D models?
faq.a2: No. Partonomy doesn't work with CAD or 3D models (STEP, DWG, IGES etc.). We focus exclusively on 2D drawings, as these make up the majority of RFQ requests and are most demanding for manual processing.
faq.q3: Does the drawing need to be perfectly readable?
faq.a3: No. Partonomy handles regular scans, poor quality or drawings forwarded from email. Better input quality means better results, but the system is designed for real RFQ operations.
faq.a4: The goal is not to replace the technologist or quotation specialist, but to significantly speed up initial drawing processing and decision-making. AI evaluates drawings based on typical manufacturing patterns and helps quickly decide if it makes sense to quote the job.
faq.q5: Who is Partonomy not suitable for?
faq.a5: Partonomy is not designed for detailed production preparation, CAD analysis or final price calculation. Greatest value is in RFQ triage – the phase of quick decision-making on incoming requests.
faq.q6: How quickly can I start and can I try it?
faq.a6: You start in a few minutes. Just register, login and upload first drawing. You get 14-day trial access for free — no installation and no credit card required.

insights.title: From RFQ drawing processing practice
insights.subtitle: One comprehensive article describing the reality of RFQ processes in manufacturing – and how the request phase can be significantly accelerated.
insights.card1Desc: Few people, many requests and pressure for quick decisions. Why RFQ is becoming a bottleneck across the company.
insights.card2Desc: Most RFQs don't arrive as CAD, but as 2D raster attachments in email. Why it's like that and what it does to the process.
insights.card3Title: How Partonomy helps in the request phase
insights.card3Desc: Not just metadata: summary, highlights, cost drivers, recommendations based on company profile, revision detection and workflow over drawing list.
insights.tip: Tip: from these sections we link directly to specific parts of the article, so you can quickly get to what's essential.

cta.title: Ready to save dozens of hours monthly?
cta.subtitle: Start analyzing drawings in 3 minutes instead of 20. First month free, no credit card, no commitments.

intro.title: Why RFQ drawing processing in manufacturing is so challenging
intro.subtitle: (and how it can be significantly simplified)
intro.lead: Processing RFQs is often one of the biggest bottlenecks in manufacturing companies. Not because people lack expertise, but because the workload is growing while capacity and tools remain the same.

rfqProblem.title: Why is RFQ drawing processing such a problem today?
rfqProblem.p1: In most manufacturing companies the scenario is similar. RFQs arrive in high volume, often under time pressure, and every drawing is different. The decision whether to engage with a job must come quickly.
rfqProblem.p2: Responsibility often lies with one or two key people — a technologist, a quotation specialist, or a senior person in production. These people become the bottleneck of the entire process.
rfqProblem.p3: Each RFQ means opening the drawing, understanding it, putting it into manufacturing context, and making an initial qualified decision. And repeating that, multiple times a day.

rasterDrawings.title: Why do most RFQs arrive as raster drawings in email?
rasterDrawings.p1: Presentations often talk about CAD data, digital twins and connected systems. But the reality of RFQ processes is much more down-to-earth.
rasterDrawings.p2: Most requests arrive via email as attachments — PDF, TIFF, PNG, sometimes even scanned legacy documentation. These drawings are not structured and are not machine-readable.
rasterDrawings.p3: This is not an ideal state, but the reality of supply chains. And it is very unlikely to fundamentally change in the near future.

manualTranscript.title: What information is manually transcribed from drawings today?
manualTranscript.intro: To make a decision on a job, someone typically has to manually extract key information from the drawing:
manualTranscript.outro: This information is then entered into ERP systems, spreadsheets or notes. Everyone does it differently, without a consistent structure. The same work is repeated again and again.

chaos.title: Why are drawings scattered across folders and nobody can find anything?
chaos.p1: After a few months of operation, it often looks the same in many companies: drawings in emails, local folders, shared drives.
chaos.p2: There is no unified overview, decision history, or an easy way to return to drawings. Every new RFQ is handled as if it were the first one ever.

taxonomy.title: Why is there no consistent taxonomy and overview of parts?
taxonomy.p1: Each drawing is described differently. One person writes “shaft”, another “axle”, someone else uses an internal name. Without a consistent taxonomy, data cannot be analyzed or learned from.
taxonomy.p2: Yet the history of drawings and decisions is extremely valuable — it’s just locked inside unstructured documents.

firstMinutes.title: What can be decided within the first minutes of looking at a drawing?
firstMinutes.p1: An experienced technologist often knows within minutes whether the part fits production, whether it is risky, or whether it makes no sense to quote at all.
firstMinutes.p2: The problem isn’t decision-making itself — it’s that each decision costs time and mental capacity, and there are many such decisions every day.

rfqTriage.title: How can automation speed up the RFQ phase (RFQ triage)?
rfqTriage.p1: If the drawing were analyzed automatically, key information structured, and the result available within minutes, it would change the nature of the RFQ phase entirely.
rfqTriage.p2: Manual processing of each drawing would become fast decision-making over ready-to-use information.

partonomy.title: Where Partonomy fits in
partonomy.p1: Partonomy was created directly from this reality. It doesn’t focus only on “reading” the drawing, but on truly understanding the part and its manufacturing implications.

list.item2: identification of critical points and cost drivers
list.item4: personalized recommendations based on the company profile
list.item6: a clear drawing list and RFQ workflow

partonomy.outro: The goal is not to replace the technologist, but to eliminate manual transcription, reduce chaos, and free up people’s capacity for decisions that truly require experience.
